items.description: North Sea at Scarborough - Foreshore Road
items.message: This flood warning has been issued due to forecast overtopping waves and spray expected as a result of high spring tides and strong winds. Consequently, flooding of property and roads and farmland is expected on the high tide between 06:30 and 08:00 on Sunday 20/02/2022. Areas most at risk are properties on Foreshore Road. Coastal conditions are expected to remain unsettled on subsequent tides and further warnings may be issued.  Please put your flood plan into action and be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast and will update this message by 21:00 on Saturday 19/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

Saturday afternoon's tide at 13:15 on 19/02/2022 is forecast to be higher than normal and similar to Friday afternoon 18/02/2022. Gale Force 8 South Westerly winds and large waves increase tide table values by 0.55 m. The total forecast tide is 6.28 metres Chart Datum (3.23 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, waves will overtop the sea front. Water will flow westwards along Mill Lane and Climping Street (from the right of the East car park) ponding in Climping Street car park, near to properties, and in nearby land and fields. Strong winds and large waves will continue over the weekend, albeit not as extreme. After Saturday, the next highest tide is forecast to be 20 cm lower, on Monday afternoon. However, spray and minor flood impacts will continue this weekend. We continue to monitor the forecast and have staff on standby to check the condition of the beach at Climping. Please take action to protect property on Climping Street at least 2 hours before high tide. Avoid visiting the sea front. We will update this message by 20:00 on 19/02/2022.

Saturday afternoon's tide at 13:15 on 19/02/2022 is forecast to be higher than normal and similar to Friday afternoon 18/02/2022. Gale Force 8 South Westerly winds and large waves increase tide table values by 0.56 m. The total forecast tide is 5.28 metres Chart Datum (2.54 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. For 1 hour either side of high water, flooding will affect Shore Road and a small number of properties in Bosham High Street and Gloucester Terrace. Water will reach the top of slipways in West Itchenor. Friday eveningâ€™s tide will be 50 cm lower than the Friday and Saturday afternoon tides. Strong winds and large waves will continue over the weekend, albeit not as extreme. After Saturday, the next highest tide is forecast to be 20 cm lower, on Monday afternoon. However, spray and minor flood impacts will continue this weekend. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. We will update this message by 20:00 on 19/02/2022.

items.description: River Severn at the Showground and The Quarry, Shrewsbury
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Welshbridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible today, Saturday, 19/02/22. We expect flooding to affect offices at the showground and Gravel Hill Lane. 
Predicted peak at Welshbridge 3.4m to 3.7m on Saturday evening. 
Further heavy rainfall is forecast on Saturday and into Sunday. This rain will cause river levels to remain high over the next few days with the possibility of further rises on Monday. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by 6pm on 19/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Severn Ham, Tewkesbury
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Mythe Bridge river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected from this afternoon 19/02/2022.  We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Severn Ham, Tewkesbury. Predicted Peaks:- at Mythe 3.6m to 4.2m on Monday, Upper Pound  3.6m to 4.2m on Monday.   
  We expect river levels to remain high into next week. More rain is forecast over the next few days that may cause river levels to rise further.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid contact with flood water and move possession and valuables off the ground or to safety.  
This message will be updated  by 5pm this afternoon 19/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: The flood alert for the Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall remains in force for the high tide on Saturday evening 19/02/2022, with overtopping waves and spray caused by strong winds expected between 7:00 PM and 9:30 PM. The particular area at risk is Kilnsea Village. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. Unsettled conditions are expected over the coming days and this alert may need to remain in force. We will continue to monitor the forecast closely. This message will be updated on Saturday evening, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because we have local information that water levels are remaining high and wind is still pushing water levels up on the River Thurne. High water is expected somewhere in the region of 3pm, and water levels are already high, from 2pm this afternoon, Saturday 19th February, and for at least the next 24hrs. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed and winds ease. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boatyards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. However, stormy conditions are pushing in from tomorrow and may delay water levels receding. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Sunday 20th February.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 12:30pm and 2:30pm lunchtime today, Saturday 19th February. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea seafront may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.83 mAODN at 1:30pm, on Saturday 19th February, which is 0.55m above tide tables, wind Force 8, South-Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables).   The tide on Sunday 20th February at 1:45am is also currently forecast to be a Flood Alert, so we will send a new message before that tide. You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 4pm today, Saturday 19th February.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.60mAOD at 16:15 today, Saturday 19th February and 4.60mAOD at 04:45 tomorrow morning, Sunday 20th February.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 90 cubic metres per second and is forecast to rise slowly over the next 48 hours. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 12:00 on Sunday 20th February, or as the situation changes.

Whilst we are not expecting any further flooding impacts on Saturday 19/02/2022, the high tide at lunch time on Sunday 20/02/2022 is expected to be higher than normal and may result in us issuing a flood warning.
Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale. 
People in the areas should consider taking action now. We urge all people to take care and not drive through flood water.
We will continue to work with emergency services and local authorities and to keep closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated by Sunday morning 20/02/2022 or if the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message: This Flood Alert was issued due to the high tide forecast at 01:00 PM on 19/02/2022. Storm Eunice brought strong winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the coast. The high tide at 01:45 AM on 20/02/2022 is not expected to reach Flood Alert, however, the tide at 01:45 PM on 20/02/2022 is expected to reach Flood Alert. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will re-issue alerts/warnings if necessary and our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Plan driving routes to coastal roads, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this evening on 19/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Further rain overnight is expected to cause the river level to rise tomorrow morning, Sunday 20/02,2022.
Areas most at risk include Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue alerts or warnings if necessary.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated on Sunday morning 20/02/222 or as the situation changes.

River levels rose as a result of persistent rainfall throughout yesterday from Storm Eunice, 18/02/2022. Consequently, surface water issues and flooding of roads and farmland is possible.
River levels are now falling but will begin to rise again around 13:00 today, 19/02/2022, as a result of further persistent, heavy,  rainfall. 
Skipton Washlands, Snaygill Ings, and Cononley Washlands are currently draining, but may begin to fill again as river levels rise a result of further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are monitoring the forecast and checking defences.  
Given the stormy conditions, stay well away from watercourses and report any issues on our Incident Hotline 0800 80 70 60. This message will be updated by 17:30 on 19/02/2022 or as the situation changes.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre and the road from Maesbrook to Melverley may be flooded. 
Peaks:- Llanymynech peaked at 4.22m Friday afternoon 18/02/22. The level at the Cae Howel gauge is 4.92m and rising slowly. 
Further heavy rainfall is forecast on Saturday and into Sunday. This rain will cause river levels to remain high over the next few days with the possibility of further rises on Sunday. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by 6pm on 19/02/22, or as the situation changes.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Other locations that may be affected include the A438, Byford, Bredwardine and Hereford. 
Predicted peaks:- Hay on Wye peaked at  2.6m Friday evening 18/02/22,  Bredwardine peaked at 4.6m overnight Friday, Belmont peaked at 4.7m early Saturday morning. Old Wye Bridge is predicted to peak at 4.2m to 4.3m Saturday morning, Mordiford 4.4m to 4.6m Saturday afternoon, Ross on Wye 3.7m to 4.0m Saturday night. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the weekend that could cause river levels to rise again. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: The flood alert has been issued for the Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby. River levels remain high due to recent rainfall and are expected to rise through this morning, Saturday 19/02/2022. The current river level in York is 2.6m. The current river level at Naburn is 2.2m. Low lying land around the River Ouse is at risk of flooding. The current forecast indicates that the river Ouse at York will peak just below 2.9m late on Saturday morning. The Foss Barrier may be operated during Saturday. Levels are forecast to fall slowly during the day on Sunday. Further significant rain is forecast for Sunday, which may cause levels on the River Ouse to rise again from Sunday evening until Tuesday morning. Flood warnings might be issued as a result of this rain. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Visit the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. This message will be updated by 4:00pm on 19/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are falling on the River Thame following rainfall over the last few days. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 19/02/2022, especially around Stadhampton and Dorchester. 
Further rain is forecast later this morning, 19/02/2022, which has the potential to be heavy at times. This rain should then clear, leaving this evening mainly dry with a few outbreaks of rain overnight.
River levels are now below the flood risk threshold at Thame. Levels remain high but within banks around Stadhampton and Dorchester. Levels have stabilised at Stadhampton and are slowly falling at Dorchester. Levels will remain high as water makes it way downstream and remain sensitive to further rainfall.
Our incident response staff have been in the area clearing trash screens. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 19/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

Strong winds are expected to continue on the Bristol Channel on Sunday, coinciding with spring tides. We are expecting this to cause large waves and a tidal surge along the coast. 
First Forecast high water is 09:30 on 20/02/22 with a level of 7.34 mAOD and a Force 7 Westerly wind. Second forecast high water is 21:45 on 20/02/22 with a level of 6.66 mAOD and a Force 7 Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. 
Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. We expect flooding to affect the Severn Estuary at Severn Beach including New Passage and Pilning. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
We will update this message as the situation changes.

We will continue to work with emergency services and local authorities and to keep closely monitoring the situation.
This message will be updated by Sunday morning 20/02/2022 or if the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high but within banks on the River Ray. Levels are gradually falling although will remain sensitive to further rainfall. Flooding of low lying roads and farmland is possible today,19/02/2022, in the area around Islip.
Further rain is forecast later this morning, 19/02/2022, which has the potential to be heavy at times. This rain should then clear, leaving this evening mainly dry with a few outbreaks of rain overnight.
Levels are currently within banks and forecast to continue gradually falling today, but remain sensitive to further rainfall.

items.description: North Cornwall coast from The Rumps to Hartland Point excluding Bude
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
High tide on the morning of Saturday 19th February has now passed and the immediate risk of flooding has reduced. However, although the worst of the weather has passed, tide levels on Saturday evening and Sunday morning are forecast to remain high and be accompanied by up to force 8 southwesterly winds. This could cause a surge of up to 340mm under the current forecast and present a risk of flooding to locations including Port Quin, Port Isaac, Port Gaverne, Trebarwith Strand and Boscastle.  

We will continue to monitor the situation and update if further flooding is expected a Flood Alert will be re-issued this afternoon, Saturday 19th February. 

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio.  

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; the observed high tide level at Ilfracombe this morning, Saturday 19th February, was 4.62 mAOD.  This was 0.21m above the astronomical tide level.

items.message:
The risk of property flooding from the sea on the North Coast of Devon has now reduced. As Storm Eunice clears the County, large waves and Storm force winds will continue to make conditions near the coast hazardous over the high spring tides which peak on Saturday morning. Tide levels are falling, however there remains a risk of wave overtopping to quays, low lying land and roads. Therefore a Flood Alert will remain in force over this period across the North Devon Coast. We will update this message following Saturday morningâ€™s high tide. 

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.

Rainfall forecast over the weekend is not expected to result in Main River flooding. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.

No further flooding is expected on Monday and Tuesday; however, stormy conditions are forecast on Wednesday, which, combined with high tides, may lead to further flooding. Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio.

River levels are rising due to recent rain. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Highley to Tewkesbury. Locations that may be affected include Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke, Upton upon Severn, South Quay, Diglis Parade and Hylton Road towpath. Flooding from drains may also be affecting Worcester racecourse and County cricket ground. 

Predicted peaks: Bewdley 3.6 to 3.9m; Worcester 4.0 to 4.5m and Diglis 3.8 to 4.2m on Sunday, 20/02/22. Kempsey Yacht Club 5.8 to 6.2m and Saxons Lode 4.1 to 4.5m on Monday.

More rain is forecast over the next few days that may cause river levels to remain high.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near local rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 5pm on Saturday, 19/02/22, or as the situation changes.

Saturday afternoon's tide at 13:15 on 19/02/2022 is forecast to be higher than normal and similar to Friday afternoon 18/02/2022. Gale Force 8 South Westerly winds and large waves increase tide table values by 0.55 m. The total forecast tide is 6.28 metres Chart Datum (3.23 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, waves will overtop the sea front. Water will flow westwards along Mill Lane and Climping Street (from the right of the East car park) ponding in Climping Street Car Park, near to properties, and in nearby land and fields. Strong winds and large waves will continue over the weekend, albeit not as extreme. After Saturday, the next highest tide is forecast to be 20cm lower, on Monday afternoon. However, spray and minor flood impacts will continue this weekend. We continue to monitor the forecast and have staff on standby to check the condition of the beach at Climping. Please take action to protect property on Climping Street at least 2 hours before high tide. Avoid visiting the sea front. We will update this message by 20:00 on 19/02/2022

Saturday afternoon's tide at 13:15 on 19/02/2022 is forecast to be higher than normal and similar to Friday afternoon (18/02/2022). Gale Force 8 South Westerly winds and large waves increase tide table values by 0.56 m. The total forecast tide is 5.28 metres Chart Datum (2.54 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. For 2 hours either side of high water, strong winds and large waves will generate a significant amount of overtopping which will affect beach top properties at the end of West Sands Lane and Medmerry. Friday eveningâ€™s tide will be 50cm lower than Friday afternoon. Strong winds and large waves will continue over the weekend, albeit not as extreme. After Saturday, the next highest tide is forecast to be 20cm lower, on Monday afternoon. However, spray and minor flood impacts will continue this weekend. We continue to monitor the forecast. Stormy seas are dangerous, with shingle debris contained, carried and thrown in the spray. Avoid Medmerry sea front at high tide. We will update this message by 20:00 on 19/02/2022

Saturday afternoon's tide at 13:15 on 19/02/2022 is forecast to be higher than normal and similar to Friday afternoon 18/02/2022. Friday eveningâ€™s tide will be 50cm lower than Friday afternoon. Strong winds and large waves will continue over the weekend, albeit not as extreme. After Saturday, the next highest tide is forecast to be 20cm lower, on Monday afternoon. However, spray and minor flood impacts will continue this weekend. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. Avoid driving on Mill Lane at high tide. We will update this message by 20:00 on 19/02/2022

items.description: Coast from Fairlight to Dungeness including the Tidal Rother

items.message:
Flood Alert in force: Coast from Fairlight to Dungeness including the Tidal Rother.

Flooding is possible for: Coast and tidal areas from Fairlight to Dungeness including Dungeness, Lydd, Camber, Winchelsea Beach, Pett Level and the Tidal Rother to Rye, Rye Harbour and East Guldeford.

Large, powerful waves are expected to affect coastal areas through the day between Fairlight and Dungeness on Saturday 19 February 2022.  Tides will be at their highest between 10:45 and 14:45 today. A peak level of 3.93 metres above Ordnance Datum is forecast at Rye Harbour at 12:45. Due to the strong winds, levels remain high and wave overtopping may continue through the day.  Flooding may affect locations near the coast in this area, particularly around Pett, Rye Harbour, and Lydd Ranges. Strong Force 8 winds will remain today.
Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond.
Members of the public are advised to stay away from frontages, due to the risk of wave overtopping.
This message will be updated during this evening, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Stour and Smestow Brook in the Black Country and South Staffordshire
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Stourbridge river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible to begin from 14:30 today, 19/02/22.     
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high throughout Saturday, 19/02/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.
Stay aware in case further warnings are issued
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 20/02/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Brimscombe river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to begin between this afternoon 19/02/2022.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Elmore to Sharpness. Other locations that may be affected include Chalford, Leonard Stanley and Cambridge.   
  We expect river levels to remain high over the weekend. More rain is forecast over the next few days that may cause river levels to rise further.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 10am tomorrow morning, 20/02/2022, or as the situation changes.
